items.title: Scalability- Types, Advantages & Disadvantages
items.author: Anav Chug
items.description:
What is Scalability?

The ability of a computer to flexibly expand or reduce its computational power, size, and resources dependent on the amount of workload or requests it receives is known as scalability. This becomes critical when a company wishes to expand its resources (or output) to meet the demands of a growing number of customers. Scalability is another crucial aspect of capacity planning. It is of two types- Horizontal Scaling and Vertical Scaling.

What is Horizontal Scaling?

Horizontal scaling is increasing the number of machines available so that multiple client requests can be distributed and processed efficiently. It’s also known as Scaling Out or Scaling In, depending on whether we’re adding or subtracting machines based on the number of requests we receive. Cloud horizontal scaling, on the other hand, refers to adding more servers to satisfy the client’s needs so that the load of requests is distributed among these servers.

Advantages of Horizontal scaling-

1. We can effectively share load by utilizing independent servers.

2. Servers can recover fast, implying that they are more resilient.

3. Scaling and upgrading the servers is simple.

4. Fault tolerance becomes reasonably straightforward.

5. In terms of how many users are added, scaling is linear.

6. The server may be scaled practically endlessly.

Disadvantages of Horizontal Scaling-

1. A lot of more components are needed, such as load balancers, routers, and virtualized software.

2. The licensing charge is more expensive.

3. It is reliant on network communication, which, like vertical scaling, is less efficient than internal communication.

4. Because numerous servers are used, more resources, such as energy, are required.

5. This type of scalability is prone to issues such as data inconsistency.

6. It produces a larger carbon footprint, which is harmful to the environment.

What is Vertical Scaling?

The goal of vertical scaling is to boost the processing capabilities (RAM, CPU, storage, and so on) of our existing computers so that they can process and handle more data. It’s also known as Scaling Up or Scaling Down, depending on whether we’re adding or decreasing computational power in response to the number of requests.

Advantages of Vertical scaling-

1. No extra components, such as load balancers, switches, or routers, are required.

2. There are no inconsistencies in the data.

3. Inter-process communication is faster and more efficient because there is only one machine.

4. There is a reduction in power consumption.

5. Licensing fees are less expensive than horizontal scaling.

6. This form of scaling is simple to implement.

Disadvantages of Vertical Scaling

1. It has only one point of failure, which means that if the machine fails for any reason, the related apps will stop running.

2. Although a server’s scalability can be increased, each server’s scalability has a finite limit.

3. The dangers of downtime are fairly significant.

4. A lot of upkeep is required

5. In vertical scaling, there are numerous vendor-lock issues.

6. High costs are involved in investment.

Differences between Horizontal and Vertical Scaling-

items.title: Encryption-Working, Use-cases, and Challenges
items.author: Anav Chug
items.description:
You might have read this message on your WhatsApp messenger that says “Messages you send to this chat and calls are now secured with end-to-end encryption.” Now, what WhatsApp means by this is that no third party including the WhatsApp team itself can read or listen to your conversations with any of your contacts. But what is encryption? And why exactly do we need it?

What is Encryption?

Encryption is the process of converting a human readable simple plain text or data into a complex cipher code before allocating that data into some storage system. The basic idea behind encryption is to prevent the data from being accessed by pernicious and unauthorized users. Any organization that deals with user data on a daily basis must utilize standardized encryption methods to ensure that their clients’ information is not stolen or compromised. It’s vital to remember that the encrypted data must be decrypted before it can be read.

How does encryption work?

In encryption, we make use of keys to encrypt and decrypt data. A key can be thought of as a combination of different numbers and letters that contains some information. It gives the data the appearance of a random cypher text. To perform these data transformations, two types of methods or algorithms are commonly used: Symmetric encryption and Asymmetric encryption.

· Symmetric Encryption- In this type of encryption, the keys that are used for encrypting and decrypting data are the same. It is considered relatively faster than asymmetric encryption due to this reason. Because the same key is used for encryption and decryption, keeping that key secure is a major challenge.

To understand symmetric encryption, let us take a hypothetical example in which we take a plaintext “Music” and use a key “2kf6453ke9” to encrypt it and generate a cipher text “X7bKECibg12.” We then use the same key “2kf6453ke9” to decrypt that cipher text back into the plaintext “Music.”

· Asymmetric (or public key) Encryption- In this type of encryption, the keys that are used for encrypting and decrypting data are different. The encryption key is called the public key and the decryption key is known as the private key. However, the public key does not need to be secured, and any unauthorized entity attempting to access it will be unable to decrypt any data.

Let us go back to our previous example in which we take the same plaintext “Music.” Notice that the only change in this example is in the type of keys used for encryption and decryption. Assume that the public key is the same (as used previously) and the private key is “3fy451oc8.”

Why do we need encryption?

The CIA triad model is adhered to by the vast majority of security systems and policies. CIA is an abbreviation for Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability. Encryption ensures that data communicated between users remains confidential, that its integrity is maintained, and that it is always available for use.

Confidentiality means that the data must be kept private and should be out of the reach of unauthorized users. It also ensures that no malicious user can access or interpret the data in any way.

Integrity refers to the fact that the data transmitted or provided by the user must be accurate and not tampered with.

Availability means that the data is readily available and accessible to the clients as well as to those within the organization. All the systems including various servers and networks must be working.

Types of Data that is encrypted-

· Data in-transit- Data that is moving (or is in-transit) needs to be encrypted before its transmission, decrypted, and verified at its destination. Uploading files to a cloud storage service, completing a form on a website, or checking your blood pressure using an app are all examples of data in transit. The HTTPS or TLS 1.2 protocol is commonly used for encryption. This protocol works by dividing the data into several sections, mixing them together using an algorithm and a public key, and then unpacking it with a private key.

· Data at rest- Data is considered to be at rest if it is not being used or sent and is stored on a storage device such as a hard disc, the cloud, or a pen drive. This information is safeguarded by a variety of security access controls that govern what data can be accessed and by whom. The encryption algorithms used to encode such data must be extremely strong, such as RSA and AES, which are asymmetric and symmetric encryptions respectively. It is also advised that the complete database, as well as the fields containing Protected Health Information (PHI) such as name, age, and date of birth, be encrypted.

Use cases of Encryption

· It aids in the protection of data stored in databases.

· It’s used in cloud-based apps to encrypt various storage systems.

· It facilitates in the secure processing of payments.

· It’s a popular choice for digital signatures.

· Communication platforms such as WhatsApp and Signal use it.

Encryption Challenges

· If the user loses the decryption keys and does not make any copies of his data, he may suffer data loss.

· Using encryption methods can be a difficult process, and some users may handle these tools incorrectly, putting their data’s security at risk.

items.title: Five Popular Cloud Services
items.author: Anav Chug
items.description:
What are cloud services?

Cloud services refer to the services provided by cloud providers that make diverse applications, resources, and virtual infrastructure available to consumers over the Internet. This eliminates the necessity for on-premise servers as well as physical interaction between customers and service providers. Cloud applications can be used as utilities over the Internet with a pay-as-you-go approach. These services are adaptable, dependable, scalable, and cost-effective.

1. AWS Lambda- AWS Lambda is a computing platform (provided by Amazon)that enables customers to run programs without the requirement of servers. The user must simply develop functioning code in one of Lambda’s supported languages, such as Node.js, Java, C#, Python, and others, and then upload it to Lambda. There is no need for the user to be concerned about running, configuring, or managing any servers. The code-running program can be simply scaled up in response to each trigger it gets. Because this is a cloud service, it operates on a pay-as-you-go basis, which means the customer only pays for the time his code is executing on AWS Lambda.

Use Cases of AWS Lambda-

  • Using AWS Lambda, we can quickly process and transform photos in a variety of formats. This may be accomplished by uploading photos to S3 buckets and triggering the Lambda function whenever a new object is added to the bucket.
  • Data from social media handles can also be examined using AWS Lambda. This can be accomplished by putting the data into an Amazon Kinesis stream and activating a Lambda function to save it in a database. Companies as large as Coca-Cola and Nordstrom have benefited from AWS Lambda.

Similar services-

  • Google Cloud Functions- Although Google Cloud Functions requires fewer steps to deploy functions, AWS Lambda can deploy and modify functions faster than GCF.
  • Azure Functions- One significant distinction between AWS Lambda and Azure Functions is that in AWS Lambda, lambda functions can be used as an independent program and Azure functions, on the other hand, are grouped together in an application.
  • Salesforce Heroku- AWS Lambda is a serverless platform, whereas Heroku has a traditional architecture.

Other services similar to AWS Lambda include Alibaba Function Compute and IBM OpenWhisk.

2. Google Compute Engine (GCE)- Google Compute Engine (GCE) is a Google Cloud Platform component that allows users to access preconfigured and customizable Virtual Machines (VCs). According to their workload, users can easily select the exact number of virtual CPUs and memory. General-purpose, compute-optimized, memory-optimized, and accelerator-optimized machines are the three machine families offered by GCE. These are divided into categories based on the type of task that a user desires. To use GCE, the user merely needs to choose the type of machine and the geographic location where the VM instance will be created. GCE offers live migration, which means we can keep our apps operating even when they are in maintenance mode. It also makes instance size suggestions based on the amount of workload, allowing the user to save money.

Use cases of Google Compute Engine-

  • It’s a lot easier to move existing systems to Google Cloud with the help of GCE.
  • By adding their own licenses or utilizing the previously provided licensed photos, the user can run a variety of Windows applications.

Similar Services-

  • Amazon EC2- GCE is used by Google Cloud to store images, whereas Amazon EC2 uses Amazon S3 or Amazon EBS to preserve image files.
  • Azure Virtual Machines- GCE normally starts in 30 seconds, however Azure VMs can take several minutes to start. Low priority instances are temporary instances provided by Azure, while preemptible VMs are temporary instances provided by the compute engine. These instances have the same functionality as one another, but different price modules.

Other services similar to Google Compute Engine include IBM Cloud Virtual Servers and Alibaba Elastic Compute Service.

3. Azure Backup- Azure Backup is a cloud-based backup service that does not require any infrastructure. Users can simply backup and restore files, virtual machine data, folders, SQL databases, and more using Azure Backup. It has security mechanisms and safeguards users’ data from threats such as ransomware. Users can also enable multi-factor authentication, which restricts backup operations to only those who are allowed. In the event that backed-up data is accidentally deleted, the user can always restore his files via Azure Backup, which keeps the data for up to two weeks.

Use cases of Azure Backup-

  • Companies with on-premises servers may quickly backup their data to the cloud with Azure Backup. As a result, they do not need to hunt for on-premise backup options.
  • The Azure Backup Recovery Services vault allows users to monitor their data and receive notifications in the event of a problem.
  • It has three types of data replication characteristics, each of which replicates different copies of data in different regions.

Similar Services-

  • AWS Backup- Although AWS Backup offers more control and customization possibilities, Azure is more centralized towards businesses, with backup services built-in and help available with a single click.
  • GCP Backup- In comparison to Azure’s centralized business model, GCP backup emphasizes integrated networking and easy operation via a single API.

Other services similar to Azure Backup include IBM Spectrum Protect and Salesforce Data Loader.

4. IBM Cloudant- IBM Cloudant is a software service developed by IBM that securely hosts and maintains a user’s data with the assistance of big data experts. IBM engineers handle database monitoring and maintenance so that developers can concentrate only on developing their apps. Mobile, web, IoT, and serverless applications are all supported by IBM software. Its long-lasting replication algorithms are meticulously engineered to ensure that data flows between the application and the database without interruption. The replicas of the users’ data are available for both read and write, unlike traditional databases.

Use cases of IBM Cloudant-

  • Cloudant enables businesses to scale their data layer, allowing users to concentrate on developing their apps.
  • In ML models, it can be used to store production data.
  • Cloudant is used by businesses to replicate data across several platforms.

Similar Services-

  • Amazon DynamoDB- The languages .Net, ColdFusion, Erlang, Groovy, Perl, and Python are supported by Amazon DynamoDB, which are not supported by IBM Cloudant. Some users prefer DynamoDB over Cloudant for a variety of reasons, including productivity and expense predictability. Others, on the other hand, prefer the Cloudant-supported JSON file format.
  • Google Cloud Firestore — Google Cloud Firestore is a NoSQL DaaS that is more user-friendly than IBM Cloudant.
  • MongoDB- MongoDB provides customers with a more flexible and adaptive approach to data storage, and many users prefer it to IBM Cloudant due to its greater document management capabilities.

Other services similar to IBM Cloudant include Azure Cosmos DB.

5. Alibaba Anti DDoS Pro- Alibaba offers a security service that guards against Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) threats. In these attacks, a certain website or server is flooded with a large number of requests on purpose. This causes the server to crash, and even legitimate requests are not processed as a result. Using common encryption techniques and protection algorithms like IP+Cookie and IP+Key, the Anti DDoS Pro solution mitigates these attacks. Other forms of attacks that this service protects against include HTTPS floods and weak connections. It also ensures that SSL private keys are secure.

Use cases of Alibaba Anti DDoS Pro-

  • It can assist enterprises by supplying them with DDoS attack defence reports.
  • Using identity recognition and multi-faced recognition technologies, websites can distinguish between malicious and legal requests.

Similar Services-

  • AWS Shield- One significant difference between AWS Shield and Alibaba Anti DDoS Pro is that Anti DDoS Pro has built-in monitoring capabilities, whereas AWS Shield uses third-party monitoring services.

Other services similar to Alibaba Anti DDoS Pro include Azure DDoS Protection, IBM Cloud Internet Services, and Google Cloud Armor.

items.title: Understanding GitHub
items.author: Anav Chug
items.description:
What is GitHub?

GitHub is a service hosted on the Internet that stores all the projects (developed and undeveloped) of a large number of users. GitHub has a repository in which the user can store various types of files and folders. This can include things like images, coding files, or any other data. Each project is stored in a distinct repository and has a unique URL.

How is it used?

  • GitHub can be used by simply signing up and creating an account on github.com .
  • After creating an account, the user can create a repository by clicking on the “Start a project” option.
  • Then the user has to enter certain details about the repository they are about to create.
  • Each user can choose between creating a public (which are free of cost) or private repository (which are paid).

The following are some of the most important features and commands used in GitHub:

  • Branches- Users can simultaneously work with multiple versions of repositories by using GitHub branches. The default branch is known as the Master Branch and the user can create various sub- branches within the master branch. Sub branches can be created through the “Branch: master” dropdown option.
  • Pull- Whenever a user makes changes in a particular file, then the pull command helps to notify those changes to other developers who can see these changes and merge it with the master branch if they want. This can be done by clicking on the “New pull request” option under the “Pull requests” tab.
  • Commit- If a user wants to add or change things in a file then they can save these changes using the commit command. Any file can be edited by clicking on the “edit” option and writing the changes in an editor window. items.title: Understanding Basics of Git
items.author: Anav Chug
items.description:
What is Git?

Git is commonly referred to as a version control system. Simply put, a version control system keeps track of changes made to users’ code over time in a database known as a repository. Git allows users to store their code and interact with other programmers on the same project. Members of the team may readily review the project history to discover who made what changes, when they were made, and why they were done.

How to use Git?

  • Installing the Git application is all that is required to use Git.
  • The user can get related information about the installation from this link: Git — Installing Git (git-scm.com) based on the type of Operating System.

The following are some Git commands and features:

  • Branches- Users can simultaneously work with multiple versions of repositories by using Git branches. The default branch is known as the Master Branch and the user can create various sub- branches within the master branch.
  • git init- This command generates a new repository. This should be done after the installation process.
  • git clone- If the data already exists on a central or remote repository, we can use the git clone command to get a copy of it.
  • git add- A user can use the git add command to update the Git staging area with new files from the directory.
  • git commit- If a user wishes to add or alter something in a file, they can use the git commit command to save their modifications.
  • git stash- When a client wants to work on something else but is in the middle of a project and isn’t ready to commit yet, they use git stash. The git stash command can be used to stash files.
  • git push- If a user is working on a local branch and making commits on that branch, and then wishes to push those commits or modifications to a repository on a remote repository, he can do so with the push command. This command’s syntax is as follows:
  • git pull- This command allows you to get data from a remote repository and download it. When a user makes edits to a file, the pull command helps to alert other developers so that they may see the changes and merge them with the master branch if they desire.

Why is Git used?

Git is used for the following reasons-

  • It aids in the tracking of modifications to a code.
  • It helps to keep track of the people who made the modifications
  • It’s employed for collaboration because it can assist a huge group of people working on the same project.
  • Everybody can work on their own copy of the code without interfering with the work of other programmers.
  • Developers can go back to previous versions of their projects with ease. It overcomes the problem of having to regularly share the most recent code changes with other developers via various means.

Summary-

Git is a version control system and with the help of git, users can keep track of all the changes made by their team members in a repository. It has a plethora of commands like git init, git clone, git add, git commit, git stash, git push, and git pull. We can run these commands in a command prompt or an application like Git Bash. With the help of git, a large number of people can work on the same project and programmers can easily restore the previous versions of their projects easily. Everyone can easily code on their own copy of the project, make the necessary changes, and share the changes with their team members.

items.title: Virtualization and Hypervisors
items.author: Anav Chug
items.description:
What is Virtualization?

Virtualization is the process of converting physical resources such as storage devices, servers, networks, servers, and operating systems, into virtual resources. Virtual Machines (VMs) are the virtual resources developed in this way. This can be accomplished by establishing logical/virtual instances of the physical resource and then granting access to the user to use these virtual instances.

Virtualization in Cloud Computing

The rationale behind creating virtual instances is that they are relatively easy to transport in comparison to physical resources.

A pay-as-you-go strategy is used by a cloud service provider to make physical resources available to his clients. However, if the service provider began providing individual physical resources to each client, this would not be feasible because many resources would be squandered, and it would also become difficult when multiple clients want to scale up.

Users would be able to access various servers, networks, software, and applications hosted in the cloud using virtualization, rather than needing to purchase or manage these resources physically.

Host machine and Guest machine

Host Machine: The machine that is used to create a virtual machine is referred to as the Host machine

Guest Machine: The virtual machine itself is also called as the Guest machine.

Types of Virtualization-

  1. Hardware Virtualization- It’s the process for embedding and installing virtual machine software into a specific hardware system or server. Hypervisor, also known as Virtual Machine Monitor, is the virtual machine software that is installed (VMM). This lets the user to install multiple operating systems and run different apps on the abstracted hardware.

2. Desktop Virtualization- The operating system of a user is virtually stored on a particular server in the cloud in this sort of virtualization, and the user can access a virtual desktop from any device over the internet or intranet. The data of the user is saved in the cloud, not on the device he is using to access the virtual desktop (VD). Increased security, centralized management, and automatic software updates are some of the main advantages of using virtualized desktops.

3. Storage Virtualization- We have a set of varied storage devices that are managed by a single Virtual SAN/ Datacenter in storage virtualization. In a nutshell, we establish a pool of storage devices out of some virtualized storage infrastructure, and the data center maintains the data stored in this infrastructure. On the server side, we have a number of virtual machines linked to this Virtual SAN, and they appear to be connected to a single virtual storage device, the data center, from their perspective. Storage virtualization offers a number of advantages, including easy data migration, scalability of storage systems, and cost savings.

4. Network Virtualization- The goal of network virtualization is to decouple software components from hardware and network equipment so that the network’s functionality is not reliant on the physical resources that support it. Furthermore, because the majority of the features are housed in the software rather than the physical machine, we can utilize the same server for numerous purposes depending on the software loaded on it. As a result, it is feasible to package network functions in multiple virtual machines and determine where and how they should be executed. This is known as Network function virtualization or NFV. Similarly, when we virtualize this network by separating the control plane (the one that manages the network) from the data plane (the one where traffic flows), then we call it software defined networking or SDN. You may fine-tune networks for unique application use cases and apply security controls on each individual network using network virtualization.

Characteristics of Virtualization-

a) Partitioning- Multiple virtual machines are present in a single physical system during virtualization, and partitioning allows to separate these individual virtual machines from one another.

b) Isolation- This simply means that the host and guest machines must be segregated in order to avoid interfering with each other’s functionality. This is done because of security concerns.

c) Encapsulation- Configuration files, vmdk files, swap files, and a variety of other file formats are all found in virtual machines. All of these files must be encapsulated in one directory.

What are Hypervisors?

A hypervisor is a piece of software that runs on top of a hardware system to assist in the creation and management of virtual machines (VMs). It’s also known as the Virtual Machine Monitor since it lets you allocate physical resources to virtual computers. On a single hardware system, many guest machines can be created, allowing users to run different operating systems such as Ubuntu, Linux, and Windows at the same time. The hypervisor also coordinates the interactions of the hardware and virtual machines.

Types of Hypervisors

There are two types of hypervisors-

  1. Type 1 Hypervisor (or bare metal)- The type 1 hypervisor is installed directly on the host machine’s hardware and functions similarly to an operating system. This form of hypervisor doesn’t need a base OS and can access hardware resources directly. This hypervisor runs virtual machines that are directly on the computer’s infrastructure. Because there is no intermediary layer like the type 2 hypervisor, this hypervisor is very stable and efficient in terms of performance. Microsoft Hyper-V, Citrix/Xen Server, Oracle VM, and VMware ESXi are all examples of type 1 hypervisors.

2. Type 2 Hypervisor (or hosted)- The type 2 hypervisor behaves like a software application as it is installed on top of an existing operating system. This means that it is reliant on the host machine’s operating system to complete certain tasks. Because the machine’s operating system serves as an intermediary layer for this hypervisor, it’s known as a hosted hypervisor. The type 2 hypervisor is less efficient than the type 1 hypervisor because it is dependent on the OS of host machine to monitor CPU calls, memory allocation, and network components. Oracle Virtual Box, VMware Fusion, and Microsoft Virtual PC are some common examples.

items.title: Introduction to Cloud Computing
items.author: Anav Chug
items.description:
What is Cloud?

Cloud can be defined as a sea of servers that are interconnected and distributed across the earth. In simple terms, you can think of the cloud as something present at a remote location. It is not a physical unit but a network of servers that perform specific functions by responding to the requests that they receive from their clients.

What is Cloud Computing?

Cloud Computing is the means by which a user can receive computer resources and infrastructure through a network of servers to manage, process, and store their data via the Internet.

Cloud computing has solved the problem of users who used to purchase or rent servers physically to store the traffic of incoming data. This is because the cloud charges the user only for the amount of service they use i.e., it works on a pay-as-you-go model. Moreover, the resources provided to the user are easily scalable and this is one of the biggest benefits of the cloud. Amazon, Google, Microsoft, Salesforce, and IBM are just a few of the well-known companies that use and provide cloud computing services.

Deployment Models in Cloud-

Four basic deployment types are specified based on the sort of access a user desires. These include public, private, hybrid, and community cloud models.

· Public Cloud- All of the services supplied in a public cloud model are available to the general public, but it is less secure. The user can access these services either free of cost or with a very minimal charge.

· Private Cloud- Private cloud models are commonly employed by businesses to ensure that the cloud is only accessible by corporate members, making it more secure than public cloud models.

· Hybrid Cloud- Hybrid cloud is a cloud that combines public and private cloud models. In this approach, the private cloud model manages the company’s vital operations (such as important databases), while the public cloud model manages the non-critical operations (say the Email service).

· Community Cloud- A consortium of companies uses the cloud service and resources under a community cloud model. Gov Cloud and Nebula Cloud are two examples.

Service Models in cloud-

These are the reference models that cloud computing is constructed on.

· Software as a Service (SaaS)- This simply means that the cloud service provider is providing the user with a software application as a service via a medium such as the Internet. This application is usually available for a nominal cost or for free. Email, Google Apps, Salesforce, Customer Relationship Management (CRM), and other similar services are examples. SaaS is incredibly efficient, cost-effective, and scalable to the needs of the consumers.

· Platform as a Service (PaaS)- The user is given a run-time environment to run, maintain, and build their applications in this cloud computing model. Essentially, the cloud service provider supplies the user with a variety of development tools, operating systems, databases, firewalls, servers, middleware, networks, and other resources to help them tailor their data and applications. These materials are accessible via the Internet and can be scaled to meet the needs of the user. These fundamental tools are available on platforms like Google App Engine, Microsoft Azure, and AWS Lambda.

· Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS)- In an IaaS service model, the cloud service provider supplies the customer with infrastructure such as physical machines, load balancers, virtual machines, network resources, disc storage, and virtual storage devices, among other things. Physical resources are converted to virtual resources and delivered to clients via the Internet. For example- Amazon Web Services (AWS) and Google Compute Engine.

· Backup as a Service (BaaS)- Data is extremely important, and it may be safeguarded using the Backup as a Service model. The method is simple: data is backed up on a remote cloud source through the Internet regularly. Additionally, many copies of a single file are produced so that even if some copies are lost in the event of a disaster, at least one copy remains. This service model can help big businesses avoid data loss.

Applications of Cloud-

  • Cloud Gaming- Cloud gaming allows players to access a variety of different games via a cloud service provider. In essence, the user can acquire access to a virtual machine that is operating on a server someplace. The user can then use this virtual machine to play games. Depending on their usage, the customer can do so by paying a monthly or yearly fee. The fundamental benefit of adopting cloud gaming services is that the server handles all of the hardware-intensive tasks, while the user just runs the streaming software and displays the video on any device, including mobile phones, laptops, tablets, and desktop PCs. Some popular cloud gaming platforms include Xbox Cloud Gaming, GeForce Now, and Playstation Now.
  • Netflix streaming services- Netflix is one of the most popular OTT platforms, and it streams its content to millions of consumers using Amazon Web Services (AWS). Netflix caches its data using Amazon CloudFront and stores it in object storage like Amazon S3. Netflix is able to deliver its material to users all around the world as a result of this. Netflix also uses the Amazon Elastic Transcoder to convert videos into various video formats based on the device, network, and screen resolution of the user. It also keeps track of user engagements with Netflix using Amazon DynamoDB.
  • Video Editing- Although there are numerous video editing softwares available on the Internet, using the cloud to edit and generate videos allows the user to do it more quickly. The videos are housed on a cloud server, and the user’s changes are automatically synced, backed up, and saved when he edits the movie using that cloud application. This is extremely beneficial when editing a video with a group of people. It saves time because the rendering is done in the cloud, and they don’t have to share files with other members as frequently as they would with other editing tools. YouTube Video Editor, Flex Clip, WeVideo, and others are some examples.
  • Slack- Slack is a well-known communication tool that makes use of Amazon Web Services (AWS) for cloud services. The Amazon Virtual Private Cloud, for example, is in charge of Slack’s security. It also makes use of Amazon Identity and Access Management (IAS), which keeps track of individual users’ credentials as well as their responsibilities. Similarly, logs are reviewed using Amazon CloudTrail, and Amazon Route 53 is used for DNS administration.
  • Google Classroom- Google Classroom is a Google product that is part of the Google Apps for Education suite. It maintains, reads, and handles its data on the Google Cloud Platform. The benefit of using the cloud in this case is that users can view Classroom from any Internet-connected device. They employ an integrated method in which Google Docs, Slides, and Spreadsheets are linked to Google Classroom, allowing students and teachers to effortlessly upload these files as assignments and assessments.

Benefits of using Cloud-

· It is very cost-effective as it uses a pay-as-you-go model.

· The user doesn’t need to install any kind of software as they can access cloud applications directly over the Internet.

· Highly accessible, provided the user has an Internet connection.

· The user can easily scale up or scale down their resources as per need.

· It provides a vast number of deployment tools and services.

These fundamental tools are available on platforms like Google App Engine, Microsoft Azure, and AWS Lambda.

· Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS)- In an IaaS service model, the cloud service provider supplies the customer with infrastructure such as physical machines, load balancers, virtual machines, network resources, disc storage, and virtual storage devices, among other things. Physical resources are converted to virtual resources and delivered to clients via the Internet. For example- Amazon Web Services (AWS) and Google Compute Engine.

· Backup as a Service (BaaS)- Data is extremely important, and it may be safeguarded using the Backup as a Service model. The method is simple: data is backed up on a remote cloud source through the Internet regularly. Additionally, many copies of a single file are produced so that even if some copies are lost in the event of a disaster, at least one copy remains. This service model can help big businesses avoid data loss.

Applications of Cloud-

  • Cloud Gaming- Cloud gaming allows players to access a variety of different games via a cloud service provider. In essence, the user can acquire access to a virtual machine that is operating on a server someplace. The user can then use this virtual machine to play games. Depending on their usage, the customer can do so by paying a monthly or yearly fee. The fundamental benefit of adopting cloud gaming services is that the server handles all of the hardware-intensive tasks, while the user just runs the streaming software and displays the video on any device, including mobile phones, laptops, tablets, and desktop PCs. Some popular cloud gaming platforms include Xbox Cloud Gaming, GeForce Now, and Playstation Now.
  • Netflix streaming services- Netflix is one of the most popular OTT platforms, and it streams its content to millions of consumers using Amazon Web Services (AWS). Netflix caches its data using Amazon CloudFront and stores it in object storage like Amazon S3. Netflix is able to deliver its material to users all around the world as a result of this. Netflix also uses the Amazon Elastic Transcoder to convert videos into various video formats based on the device, network, and screen resolution of the user. It also keeps track of user engagements with Netflix using Amazon DynamoDB.
  • Video Editing- Although there are numerous video editing softwares available on the Internet, using the cloud to edit and generate videos allows the user to do it more quickly. The videos are housed on a cloud server, and the user’s changes are automatically synced, backed up, and saved when he edits the movie using that cloud application. This is extremely beneficial when editing a video with a group of people. It saves time because the rendering is done in the cloud, and they don’t have to share files with other members as frequently as they would with other editing tools. YouTube Video Editor, Flex Clip, WeVideo, and others are some examples.
  • Slack- Slack is a well-known communication tool that makes use of Amazon Web Services (AWS) for cloud services. The Amazon Virtual Private Cloud, for example, is in charge of Slack’s security. It also makes use of Amazon Identity and Access Management (IAS), which keeps track of individual users’ credentials as well as their responsibilities. Similarly, logs are reviewed using Amazon CloudTrail, and Amazon Route 53 is used for DNS administration.
  • Google Classroom- Google Classroom is a Google product that is part of the Google Apps for Education suite. It maintains, reads, and handles its data on the Google Cloud Platform. The benefit of using the cloud in this case is that users can view Classroom from any Internet-connected device. They employ an integrated method in which Google Docs, Slides, and Spreadsheets are linked to Google Classroom, allowing students and teachers to effortlessly upload these files as assignments and assessments.

Benefits of using Cloud-

· It is very cost-effective as it uses a pay-as-you-go model.

· The user doesn’t need to install any kind of software as they can access cloud applications directly over the Internet.

· Highly accessible, provided the user has an Internet connection.

· The user can easily scale up or scale down their resources as per need.

· It provides a vast number of deployment tools and services.
